sentence:
[Trees and cycles]
Given a tree T we denote by T the set of its leaves, Â vertices of degree 1
and by (T) its diameter, that is the maximum length (in number of edges) of a path
in T.

For every two vertices u,v âˆˆT,
there is exactly one path in T between u and v, that we denote
by uTv. Also, given that uTv has at least 2
vertices, we denote by uTv
(resp. uTv) the path uTv without vertex
u (resp. v).

Let C be a cycle on which we fixed some orientation.
Then, there is exactly one path following this orientation between any two
vertices u,v âˆˆC. Similarly, we denote this path by
uCv and we define uCv and
uCv as we did for the tree.

In a rooted tree T 
of root r, the least common ancestor of two vertices u and
v, written T(u,v) is the first common vertex of the paths
uTr and vTr. We refer to the root of T
by the notation (T).

For every integer h>0, we denote by B_h the complete binary tree
of heightÂ h.

sentence: A -graph is a graph which at each vertex has a bijection from the outgoing half-edges to the vertices of a cycle graph. Half-edges which are mapped to adjacent vertices are (formally) adjacent . Half-edges are said to be opposite if they are mapped to vertices of maximal distance in the cycle graph.

sentence: A checkerboard embedding of a  -graph Î“ into S is an embedding such that the cells of S âˆ–Î“ admit a 2-coloring under which any cells with a common edge have different colors.

sentence: Given an Euler circuit C of a -graph Î“, a 6-vertex v âˆˆÎ“ is splitting with respect to C if for some a âˆˆ C^-1({v}), C(a+Ïµ) and C(a-Ïµ) are on opposite half-edges around v, and for the other two points b, c âˆˆ C^-1({v}), C(b+Ïµ) and C(b-Ïµ) are on adjacent half-edges, and C(c+Ïµ) and C(c-Ïµ) are on adjacent half-edges.

sentence:
An expansion of as signed -chord diagram D_Î“, C a signed chord diagram D'_Î“, C such that


  * For every chord in D,Î“,C containing vertices a and b, there is a chord of the same sign in D'_Î“,C of the same sign connecting vertices a and b.

  * For every triad e in D_Î“,C containing at least one edge with positive sign, for some labeling a,b,c of the vertices of e such that the edge connecting a to the triad point is positive, D'_Î“,C contains a chord connecting a Â±Ïµ to b and a chord connecting a âˆ“Ïµ to c, with Â±Ïµ chosen in such a way that the chords are not linked. Furthermore, the chords connecting a to b and a to c in D'_Î“,C have the same signs as the edges connecting the triad point of e to b and c in D_Î“,C, respectively.

  * For every triad e in D_Î“,C in which all edges have negative sign, for some labeling a,b,c of the vertices of e, D'_Î“,C contains a chord connecting a Â±Ïµ to b and a chord connecting a âˆ“Ïµ to c, with Â±Ïµ chosen in such a way that the chords are linked. Furthermore, the chords connecting a to b and a to c in D'_Î“,C have signs opposite to the edges connecting the triad point of e to b and c in D_Î“,C, respectively.

  * For every double chord e in D_Î“,C with principal vertex a, for some labeling b, c of the nonprincipal vertices of e, there is a chord in D'_Î“,C connecting a - Ïµ to b and a chord in D'_Î“,C connecting a + Ïµ to c. These chords are not linked.

sentence:
A permissible separation of a signed chord diagram D'_Î“, C arising as an expansion of a signed -chord diagram D_Î“, C is a pair of signed chord diagrams D_W and D_B such that


  * Every chord in D'_Î“, C is in exactly one of D_W and D_B.

  * Two chords in D'_Î“, C which come from the same triad in D_Î“, C are both in D_W, or both in D_B.

  * Of any two chords in D'_Î“, C which come from the same double chord in D_Î“, C, one chord is in D_W and the other is in D_B.

sentence: Given a chord diagram D, surgery of D is the following process: For each chord e connecting points a,b, delete a neighborhood of e and connect the obtained endpoints a+Ïµ to b-Ïµ and a-Ïµ to b+Ïµ if e is positive, and a+Ïµ to b+Ïµ and a-Ïµ to b-Ïµ if e is negative. This produces a family of circles; these are called the result of surgery of D.

sentence: To form the intersection matrix of a signed chord diagram D with n chords, first enumerate the chords 1,â€¦,n. Then the intersection matrix M(D) is an n Ã— n matrix over â„¤_2, such that M_ii=1 if and only if the chord i is negative, and M_ij=M_ji=1 for i â‰  j if and only if the chords i and j are linked.

sentence:
[A'CampoÂ <cit.>]

A divide is the image of an immersion of a finite number of intervals and circles into D such that: 
(i) there is no triple point, 
(ii) there is no self-tangency, 
(iii)Â all intersections are transverse, 
(iv) both endpoints of every immersed segment lie on âˆ‚ D and the endpoints of all segments are distinct, 
(v) immersed circles do not intersect âˆ‚ D. 

We denote byÂ  the family of all isotopy classes of connected divides.

sentence:
A discal graph is a graph embedded intoÂ D such that the edges intersect âˆ‚ D in vertices only, and whose vertices are 
colored as follows: 
the vertices lying in the interior of D are black, those lying on âˆ‚ D are white. 
If there is exactly one vertex on âˆ‚ D, we can also draw a star instead of coloring in white. 

We denote byÂ  the family of all isotopy classes of discal graphs.

sentence:
Assume that P is a connected divide. 
Then the code of P is the discal graph G(P) obtained by taking one vertex in every black region of Dâˆ– P

sentence:
Assume that G and H are embedded colored graphs and that  is an ordered set. 
We say that H is a planar minor ofÂ G, written H_ G, 
if H can be obtained from G by repeatedly applying the following operations:

(i) decreasing the color of a vertex,

(ii) deleting an edge, 

(iii) contracting an edge whose ends have the same color,

(iv) deleting an isolated vertex.

sentence:
(See FigureÂ <ref>.) 
Let G be an embedded colored graph. 
A Tutte-Mazoit tree for G is an abstract binary treeÂ T_G, such that every nodeÂ v is labelled with (a) a discÂ D(v) in the plane whose boundaryÂ âˆ‚ D(v) intersectsÂ G in some vertices only, and (b) the planar decorationÂ G(v)^* of the restrictionÂ G(v) of G toÂ D(v), and such that

(i) for every leaf v ofÂ T_G, the graphÂ G(v) is 3-connected,

(ii) for every internal node v with sonsÂ v_1, v_2, the discÂ D(v) is the union of D(v_1) and D(v_2),

(iii) denoting byÂ r(T_G) the root ofÂ T_G, the graphÂ G(r(T_G)) equals the whole graphÂ G (or, equivalently, the discÂ D(r(T_G)) contains all ofÂ G).

Let G, G_1, and G_2 be graphs.  Let k â‰¥ 1 be a positive integer.  The graph G is a k-edge sum of G_1 and G_2 if the following holds.  There exist vertices v_i âˆˆ V(G_i) such that (v_i) = k for i = 1, 2 and a bijection Ï€: Î´(v_1) â†’Î´(v_2) such that G is obtained from (G_1 - v_1) âˆª (G_2 - v_2) by adding an edge from x âˆˆ V(G_1) - v_1 to yâˆˆ V(G_2) - v_2 for every pair e_1, e_2 of edges such that e_1 âˆˆÎ´(v_1), e_2=Ï€(e_1), the ends of e_1 are x and v_1, and the ends of e_2 are y and v_2.

We will also refer to a k-edge sum as an edge sum of order k.  The edge sum is grounded if  there exist vertices v_1' and v_2' in G_1 and G_2, respectively, such that for i = 1, 2, v_i' â‰  v_i and there exist k edge-disjoint paths linking v_i and v_i'.  If G can be obtained by a k-edge sum of G_1 and G_2, we write G = G_1 âŠ•Ì‚_k G_2.

sentence:
[Compare <cit.>] A finitary semimatroid is a
  triple =(S,,) consisting of a (possibly infinite) set
  S, a non-empty finite dimensional simplicial complex  on S and a bounded function :â†’ satisfying the following conditions.

  
  (R1) If Xâˆˆ, then 0â‰¤(X)â‰¤ |X|.
  
  (R2) If X,Yâˆˆ and X Y, then (X)â‰¤(Y).
  
  (R3) If X,Yâˆˆ and Xâˆª Yâˆˆ, then (X)+(Y)â‰¥(Xâˆª Y)+(Xâˆ© Y).
  
  (CR1) If X,Yâˆˆ and (X)=(Xâˆ© Y), then Xâˆª Yâˆˆ.
  
  (CR2) If X,Yâˆˆ and (X)<(Y), then Xâˆª yâˆˆ for some yâˆˆ Y-X.


If only (R1), (R2), (R3) are known to hold, we call  a locally ranked triple. 

A finite semimatroid is a finitary semimatroid with a finite ground set. Finiteness of locally ranked triples is defined accordingly.

Here, and in the following, we often write  instead of  and omit braces when representing singleton sets, thus writing (x) for ({x}) and Xâˆª x for Xâˆª{x}, when no confusion can occur.

sentence:
Let M be a matching with n arcs, and let I be an open interval on the
real line. The tangling of M in I is an operation which produces
a matching N with n+1 arcs, defined as follows. First, we reorder the
endpoints of M belonging I in such a way that all the left endpoints
in I appear to the left of all the right endpoints, while the relative
position of the left endpoints as well as the relative position of the right
endpoints remains the same. Next, we create a new short arc Î± 
whose endpoints belong to I, and which is nested below all the other arcs
that have at least one endpoint inÂ I. Let N
be the resulting matching.

sentence:
Let G be a 
graph on a linearly ordered set of edges E.
Let T be a spanning tree of G.

The 

active filtration of T in G
is the unique connected filtration of G associated to T in the decomposition given by Theorem <ref>. 
It is thus the unique filtration  âˆ…= F'_âŠ‚...âŠ‚ F'_0=F_c=F_0âŠ‚...âŠ‚ F_= E of G such that:



=0mm =0mm =0mm =0mm

  * for  1â‰¤ kâ‰¤, Tâˆ© (F_k F_k-1) is an internal  uniactive spanning tree of G(F_k)/F_k-1,

  * for  1â‰¤ kâ‰¤, Tâˆ© (F'_k-1 F_k) is an external  uniactive spanning tree of G(F'_k-1)/F'_k

(such a filtration is necessarily connected, otherwise one of the induced minors has no spanning tree with the required property, see Lemma <ref>).

The active partition of T in G is the partition of E formed by successive differences of subsets in the active filtration 

(yielding parts whose smallest elements are the internally/externally active elements of T).

 Given xâˆˆ V(H)âˆ–Ï• and vâˆˆ V_x, we form a stack of candidate graphs corresponding to the partial embedding Ï•âˆª{xâ†¦ v} according to the following update rule .  An ensemble of parameters is valid if the following statements all hold for each 1â‰¤â„“â‰¤ k.

    Î·_0    â‰¤Î·_â„“/72(k+1)c^*âˆ_0<â„“â€â‰¤â„“Î´_â„“â€^c^* ,

  *  For each râˆˆ[k-1] we have _â„“,r+1,h^*â‰¤_â„“,r,0.

  That is, with inputs Î´_â„“ and _â„“,r,h for 1â‰¤ hâ‰¤ h^* we have (4k+1)Î·_â„“-1 small enough to apply LemmaÂ <ref>.

   The graph  is an (Î·_0,c^*)-THC graph with density graph _Ï•.

  For each 1â‰¤â„“'â‰¤â„“ and âˆ…â‰  eâŠ‚ V(H)âˆ–Ï•, the graph ^(â„“')(e) is (,d)-regular with respect to ^(â„“'-1)(e), where
  
    =_â„“',|e|,Ï€_Ï•(e)   and    d=d^(â„“')_Ï•(e)=âˆ_fâŠ‚ V(H),
    eâŠ‚ f, fâˆ– eâŠ‚Ï•d^(â„“')(f) .

  
  *

    Î´_â„“'â‰¤âˆ_fâŠ‚ V(H),
     eâŠ‚ fd(f) .

 
 When we have a k-good partial embedding, we will usually simply say good partial embedding (GPE).

sentence:
A word w is rich if it has exactly |w| + 1 distinct palindromic factors. An infinite word is rich if its
    every factor is rich.

sentence:
Let w be a finite or infinite word. The privileged complexity function which counts the number of distinct
    privileged factors of length n in w is defined as
    
    _n(w) = |_n(w)|

    for all n â‰¥ 0.

sentence: An infinite word w is Sturmian if _n(w) = n+1 for all n â‰¥ 0.

sentence:
A Q-property of words is defined to satisfy the following conditions:
    
      
  - Q(Îµ) and Q(a) hold for all letters a âˆˆ A,
      
  - for every position i in every word there exists a factor with property Q ending at position i,
      
  - every position in every word introduces at most one factor with property Q.
    
    Factors with property Q are called Q-factors .

    For a finite word w we define ^Q(w) = |{u âˆˆ(w) : Q(u)}|.

An infinite word w over alphabet A (|A| â‰¥ 2) is episturmian if w has the property _n(w) and has

sentence:
An even-tempered game is an integer or a pair {G^L|G^R} where {G^L} and {G^R} are finite nonempty sets
of odd-tempered games.[We are using the standard notational abbreviations of combinatorial game theory, where
G^L and G^R are variables ranging over the left and right options of a game G.  We will use this kind of abbreviation later
in DefinitionsÂ <ref> and <ref> to save space.]  An odd-tempered game is a pair {G^L|G^R} where {G^L} and {G^R} are finite nonempty
sets of even-tempered games.  A well-tempered game is an even-tempered game or an odd-tempered game.

sentence:
The left outcome and right outcome of G, denoted (G) and (G), respectively, are recursively defined as follows:

    (G) = 
    G     if G is an integer
    max_G^L(G^L)  otherwise


    (G) = 
    G     if G is an integer
    min_G^R(G^R)  otherwise

Here max_G^L(G^L) denotes the maximum value of (G^L) as G^L ranges over the left options of G, and similarly
min_G^R(G^R) is the minimum as G^R ranges over the right options of G.

We define the outcome of G to be the pair ((G),(G)).

the right final outcome of G, denoted (G), is (G) when G is odd and (G) when G is even.

that is an integer is an element of S.  We denote the class of S-valued well-tempered scoring games ğ’²_S.

and (G + X) â‰¥(H + X) for every game X.  We define G â‰² H  H â‰³ G.

sentence:
Let G be a well-tempered scoring game.  Then we say that a left option G^L is reversible if there is some right option G^LR
of G^L with G^LRâ‰² G.  We say that a right option G^R is reversible if there is some left option G^RL of G^R
with G^RLâ‰³ G.  We say that a left option G^L is dominated if some other left option G^L' satisfies
G^L'â‰³ G^L, and we say that a right option G^R is dominated if some other right option G^R' satisfies
G^R'â‰² G^R.  If G âˆˆâ„, we say that G is canonical if it has no reversible or dominated options, and the
same is true for all subgames.

A finite, connected, biregular, bipartite
graph with valencies q_1+1 and q_2+1 is called Ramanujan bigraph if

    |Î»^2-q_1-q_2| â‰¤ 2 âˆš(q_1q_2),
 for every Î»âˆˆ{Â±Î»_2,Â±Î»_3,â€¦,Â±Î»_n_1}, where the notation is as in (<ref>).

 We call X a weak Ramanujan bigraph if Î»_n_1>0, in other words if (X) has the eigenvalue 0 with multiplicity exactly n_2-n_1.

sentence:
[characterization of m-error-correcting  P-codes] 
An (n,2^n-m) code ğ’ is an m-error-correcting P-code
if and only if the following two conditions hold:

a) â„_P^m contains exactly one ideal I;

b) there is a function f:2^P\ Iâ†’ 2^I
such that ğ’={Yâˆª f(Y) | Yâˆˆ 2^P\ I}, i. e.,
the code ğ’ is systematical with
information symbols P\ I and
check symbols I.

Every m-error-correcting P-code is an m-perfect P-code.

sentence:
Suppose PÌƒ_b is a BLUE path and PÌƒ_r a RED path.
  Then the pair (PÌƒ_b, PÌƒ_r) is a one-step path
    extension of (P_b,P_r) if exactly one of the following holds:
  
  
  * PÌƒ_b is P_b with one additional element at the end
    and PÌƒ_r = P_r, or
  
  * PÌƒ_r is P_r with one additional element at the end
    and PÌƒ_b = P_b, or
  
  * PÌƒ_b is the path P_b with the last element x_b
    removed and PÌƒ_r is P_r with x_b and some integer x
    added in that order at the end, (in this case x_b
    switches to RED), or
  
  * PÌƒ_r is the path P_r with the last element x_r
    removed and PÌƒ_b is P_b with x_r and some integer x
    added in that order at the end, (in this case x_r
    switches to BLUE).
  
 
  
  
  
  
  (PÌƒ_b,PÌƒ_r) is a path extension of
  (P_b, P_r) if it can be obtained from (P_b,P_r) by a sequence of
  one-step path extensions.  Also, if (PÌƒ_b,PÌƒ_r) is a
  path extension of (P_b, P_r), PÌƒ_r=P_r, and x is
  the last element of PÌƒ_b, then we say that
  (PÌƒ_b,PÌƒ_r) is a BLUE path extension of
    (P_b, P_r) to x .  We similarly define a RED path
    extension of (P_b, P_r) to x .

sentence:
Suppose (PÌƒ_b,PÌƒ_r) is a one-step path extension of
  (P_b,P_r) obtained by Case (3) (i.e. x_b switches to RED and is
  followed by x on PÌƒ_r.)  We say that x_b strongly
    switches to RED if there is no BLUE path extension to x.  We
  similarly define what it means for x_r to strongly switch
  to BLUE.
  
  We say (PÌƒ_b,PÌƒ_r) forms a strong one-step
    path extension of (P_b,P_r) if the pair
  (PÌƒ_b,PÌƒ_r) is a one-step path extension of
  (P_b, P_r) via either CasesÂ (1) or (2), or via CasesÂ (3) or (4)
  with a strong switch.
  
  We say that (PÌƒ_b,PÌƒ_r) forms a strong path
    extension of (P_b,P_r) if it can be obtained from (P_b,P_r)
  by a sequence of strong one-step path extensions.

sentence:
For a coloring c, we will say that we can always strongly
    RED switch if for every pair (P_b, P_r) of disjoint finite BLUE
  and RED paths, there is a strong path extension
  (PÌƒ_b, PÌƒ_r) of (P_b, P_r) such that there was
  a strong RED switch at some point during the path extension between
  (P_b, P_r) and (PÌƒ_b, PÌƒ_r).

  We define being able to always strongly BLUE switch
  similarly.

The vertex width of G is the minimum width among all edge orders of G.

sentence:
[Definition 1, <cit.>]
A tree decomposition of G is a pair ({X_i : i âˆˆ I },T ), where I is an index set, {X_i : i âˆˆ I } is a collection of subsets of V(G) and T is a tree whose node set is I, such that the following conditions are satisfied:

  * âˆ€ i,j,k âˆˆ I : if j is on a path in T from i to k, then X_iâˆ© X_kâŠ‚ X_j.


The width of a tree decomposition ({ X_i : i âˆˆ I },T) is max{|X_i| : i âˆˆ I} -1. The treewidth of G, tw(G) , is the minimum width over all tree decompositions of G.

sentence:
[Shelling sequences]  Let C be a simplicial d-complex with N facets. Assume that d (N-1) > 0. A shelling step is the removal from a pure simplicial d-complex C of a single d-face whose intersection with the remaining complex is pure (d-1)-dimensional and shellable. Given two pure simplicial d-complexes C and D, we say that â€œC shells to Dâ€, and write C â†˜_ D, if there is a sequence of shelling steps which leads from C to D. The intermediate complexes between C and D form a sequence of subcomplexes (C_i), which we call shelling sequence . By definition, C_i+1 is a subcomplex of C_i obtainable from C_i via a single shelling step.
Clearly, a complex C is shellable if and only if C shells to some facetÂ Î”.

[Pseudosimplex]
A (d-dimensional) pseudosimplex Î” in S^d is the intersection of d+1 or less hemispheres whose centers lie in convex position. The boundary âˆ‚Î” has a natural decompositon into pseudosimplices, which we will call faces . In the special case when Î” is defined by one hemisphere, we call âˆ‚Î” an equator . If p is a point, we denote by L_p the hemisphere with center p, and by E_p the equator âˆ‚ L_p.

sentence:
[p-spanning boundary complexes]
Let P be a pseudosimplex in S^d (resp. a simplex in ^d). Let M be a pure subcomplex of âˆ‚ P, either empty or (d-1)-dimensional. Let p be a point in S^d (resp.Â a vector in ^d). We say that M is p-spanning if the hemisphere centered at p contains the intersection of all facets of M or does not intersect the hemisphere at all (resp. if the unique local minimum of the scalar product âŸ¨ p, - âŸ© on M is contained in the intersection of all facets of M).

sentence:
[General position, k-split-shellable]
Let C be a simplicial complex in the sphere S^d, that is convex with respect to the standard intrinsic metric on S^d (resp. ^d). (This means that for any two points of C, a shortest arc between them is completely contained in |C|.)
A hemisphere (resp. a halfspace) H of S^d (resp. ^d) intersecting C is in general position with respect to C if no vertex of C lies in âˆ‚ H. If k is a positive integer, we say that C is k-split-shellable if for every hemisphere (resp. any halfspace) H in general position with respect to C, the shelling of ^k C can be chosen so that ^k C shells to ^k-1N^1((C,H),C), which then shells to some facet.

Let P be a polytopal complex in S^d. Let E be an equator of S^d. The E-splitting subdivision of P is the (realization of a) derived subdivision where vertices are chosen so that:
[â€“]

  * they coincide with the barycenters of those faces whose relative interior does not intersect E;

  * they lie at the barycenter of the intersection Eâˆ©Ï„, for any face Ï„ of P whose relative interior intersects the equator E.

sentence: Let N be a network with some edge e=(v,w). The operation in which we delete e, add a new vertex z, then add the edges (v,z) and (z,w) is termed subdividing e, and the new vertex z is referred to as an attachment point . The inverse operation of subdivision is termed suppressing a vertex, in which a degree 2 vertex z with edges (v,z) and (z,w) is deleted and then the edge (v,w) is added.

sentence: Let N be a network on edge set X. A cut-edge is an edge such that N-e is a disconnected graph. A pendant edge is a cut-edge where one of the connected components of N-e is trivial. We refer to N as simple if all cut-edges of N are pendant. A blob is a maximal connected subgraph of N with no cut-edges that is not a vertex.

sentence: Let N be a network and v a vertex of N. We say that v is a cut-vertex if deletion of v and all edges incident to v from N forms a disconnected graph. The connected components of this disconnected graph are referred to as the  cut-components of v in N.

sentence:
Let N be a network on leaf-set X. Then N is referred to as



  * loosely tree-based on X if there exists a spanning tree in N whose leaf-set is equal to X,

  * tree-based on X if there exists a spanning tree T of N such that T contains all edges between two vertices of degree 4 or more, and all degree 2 vertices of T were degree 3 in N, and

  * strictly tree-based on X if there exists a spanning tree T in N whose leaf-set is equal to X and T contains every edge incident to the vertices of degree at least 4.

  A (q,r)-blooming tree is an increasing ordered tree with q extra indistinguishable unlabeled nodes appended to the root, and r extra indistinguishable unlabeled nodes appended to each labeled node other than the root.

sentence:
The Cauchy-Schwarz calculus  operates with statements of the form f â‰¥ 0 with f âˆˆ and has axioms


  A1:  f^2 â‰¥ 0 for every f;

  A2:  f_1^2_T  f_2^2_T -  f_1f_2_T^2 â‰¥ 0 for f_1,f_2 and T as inÂ (<ref>).

The inference rules of the Cauchy-Schwarz calculus are


  R1:  
    f â‰¥ 0      gâ‰¥ 0/Î± f + Î² g â‰¥ 0  (Î±,Î²â‰¥ 0),


  R2:  
    f â‰¥ 0      gâ‰¥ 0/fg â‰¥ 0,


  R3:  
    f â‰¥ 0/ f _T â‰¥ 0  (T âŠ†â„•),


for f,g âˆˆ.
We say that f âˆˆ is CS-positive if the statement f â‰¥ 0 is provable in the Cauchy-Schwarz calculus.

sentence:
A planar directed graph D with no multiple edges embedded in a disk is an A_2-web if it satisfies the following conditions:

 
  * D is bipartite, with each edge of D is oriented from one of the negative vertices to one of the positive vertices, and
 
  * all the boundary vertices have degrees 1 while all internal vertices have degree 3.

If, in addition, D is non-elliptic , i.e.,

 
  (3) all internal faces of D have at least 6 sides,

then we say D is an irreducible A_2 web .

sentence: Define a twist region of D(K) to be a longest possible string of bigons in the projection graph of D(K). Denote the number of twist regions in D(K) by t(D) and call t(D) the twist number of D(K). Note that it is possible for a twist region to consist of a single crossing of D(K).

sentence: If a given twist region contains two or more crossings, then the A-resolution of a left-handed twist region will be called a long resolution and the A-resolution of a right-handed twist region will be called a short resolution . See Fig.Â <ref> for depictions of these resolutions. We will call a twist region long if its A-resolution is long and short if its A-resolution is short.

sentence:
Call an alternating tangle in D(K) a special tangle if, up to planar isotopy, it consists of exactly one of the following:





  (1) a tangle sum of a vertical short twist region and a one-crossing twist region (with the crossing type of Fig.Â <ref>)

  (2) a tangle sum of two vertical short twist regions

  (3) a tangle sum of a horizontal long twist region and a vertical short twist region 





To look for such tangles in D(K) âŠ† S^2, we look for simple closed curves in the plane that intersect D(K) exactly four times and that contain a special tangle on one side of the curve. Equivalently, the special tangles of D(K) can be found in the all-A state H_A by looking for all-A circles that are incident to A-segments from a pair of twist regions from the tangle sums mentioned above. We call these all-A circles special circles (SCs) of H_A. See Fig.Â <ref> for depictions of special tangles and special circles. Let st(D) denote the number of special tangles in D(K) (or, equivalently, the number of special circles in H_A).

sentence:
Two plabic graphs are called move-equivalent if they can be obtained
from each other by moves (M1)-(M3).  The move-equivalence class
of a given plabic graph G is the set of all plabic graphs which are move-equivalent
to G.
A leafless plabic graph without isolated components
is called reduced if there is no graph in its move-equivalence
class to which we can apply (R1).

sentence:
Let G be a reduced plabic graph 
with boundary vertices 1,â€¦, n.
The trip T_i from i is the path
obtained by starting from i and traveling along
edges of G according to the rule that each time we reach an internal black vertex we turn
(maximally) right, and each time we reach an internal white vertex we turn (maximally) left.
This trip ends at some boundary vertex Ï€(i).
In this way we associate a trip permutation
Ï€_G=(Ï€(1),â€¦,Ï€(n)) to each reduced plabic graph G,
and we say that G has type Ï€_G .
	(Because one can reverse each trip, it is clear that Ï€_G is a permutation.)

sentence:
Let G be a reduced plabic graph.  We associate a quiver Q(G) as follows.  The vertices of 
Q(G) are labeled by the faces of G.  We say that a vertex of Q(G) is frozen
if the 
corresponding face is incident to the boundary of the disk, and is mutable otherwise.
For each edge e in G which separates two faces, at least one of which is mutable, 
we introduce an arrow connecting the faces;
 this arrow is oriented so that it â€œsees the white endpoint of e to the left and the 
black endpoint to the rightâ€ as it crosses over e.  We then remove oriented 2-cycles
from the resulting quiver, one by one, to get Q(G). See <ref>.

sentence:
Let G be a graph and G' be an induced subgraph of G. If for
every maximal clique C of G', each nontrivial component of
G'-C contains a heavy vertex of G, then G' is a
clique-heavy (or in short, c-heavy ) subgraph of G.
For a given graph S, G is S-c-heavy if every induced
subgraph of G isomorphic to S is c-heavy.

sentence:
A non-empty binary matrix M=(m_i,j) of size nÃ— k, is a Dyck matrix if it satisfies the
following conditions.


  (M1) There exists 0<hâ‰¤ k such that m_1,j=1 if and only if jâ‰¤ h.

  (M2) For each 1 â‰¤ i < n, there exist 1â‰¤ a_iâ‰¤ b_i<c_iâ‰¤ k such that a_i is
    the smallest index satisfying m_i,a_i=1 and m_i+1,a_i=0, b_i is the greatest index
    such that m_i,b_i=1, and
    c_i is the greatest index such that m_i+1,c_i=1. Moreover, the following hold: 

    (M2.1) m_i+1,j=m_i,j,  for j=1,â€¦,a_i -1;

    (M2.2) m_i+1,j=0,  for j=a_i,â€¦,b_i;

    (M2.3) m_i+1,j=1,  for j=b_i+1,â€¦,c_i;

    (M2.4) m_i+1,j=0,  for j=c_i+1,â€¦,k.

sentence:
A 3-link in H is a set of 3 hyperedges h_1, h_2, h_3 âˆˆ E(H) such that h_1 âˆ© h_2  â‰ âˆ…, h_2 âˆ© h_3 â‰ âˆ… and h_1 âˆ© h_3 = âˆ…. The hyperedges h_1 and h_3 are called terminal hyperedges of this 3-link. (Notice that a given 3-link defines four different Berge paths because each end vertex can be chosen in two ways. Also note that a 3-link is simply the set of hyperedges of a linear path of length three.)  

Given a hypergraph H and abc âˆˆ E(H), let p_abc(H) denote the number of 3-links in H in which abc is a terminal hyperedge and let p(H) denote the total number of 3-links in H. Notice 
    p(H) = 1/2âˆ‘_abc âˆˆ E(H) p_abc(H).

sentence: A path in a graph G is a sequence u_1,â€¦,u_n of vertices of G so that {u_i,u_i+1}âˆˆ E, i = 1,â€¦, n-1. G is called connected if for any two vertices v and w of G there is a path u_1,â€¦,u_n in G with v=u_1 and w=u_n. G is called disconnected if it is not connected. See Figures <ref> and <ref>.

sentence: A bicolored graph is a graph where each vertex is colored with one of two colors (say, red or blue) such that no two vertices of the same color are adjacent. Suppose that T is a tabloid and T is a corresponding tableau such that, for some column indices c_1, c_2 and some nonnegative integers i, k, l, column c_1 of T is filled (in order from top to bottom) with the elements i+1, i+2, â€¦, i+k+l and column c_2 is filled with the elements i+k+l+1, i+k+l+2, â€¦, i+k+2l.  Then the forward column rebase of type (i, k, l) of T is the sequence of tableaux (T = T_0, T_1, â€¦, T_(k + l) Â· l), where T_j is formed from T_j - 1 by switching the elements in positions ((k + l)m - j + 1, c_1) and (m, c_2), where m = âŒˆ j/(k + l)âŒ‰ is the unique integer such that

    (k + l) Â· (m - 1) + 1 â‰¤ j â‰¤ (k + l) Â· m.
 
We say that the reversed sequence is the backward column rebase of T' := T_(k + l) Â· l.  The forward column rebase of T is the sequence of tabloids that we get by forgetting the row orders in every tableau in the forward column rebase of T, and similarly for the backward column rebase of the tabloid T' associated to T'.

sentence: S is a minimal separator if no proper subset of S is a separator. Similarly, S is a minimal ab-separator if no proper subset of S separates a and b. Finally, S is a minimal vertex separator if it is a minimal separator for some pair of vertices.

sentence: A graph G is a threshold graph if it can be constructed recursively from K_1 by successively adding either a dominating vertex or an isolated vertex.

sentence: A graph with (perhaps) loops is loop-threshold if it can be obtained from K_1, or K_1 with a loop, by successively adding an unlooped isolated vertex, or a looped dominating vertex.

  and cyclic shifts.

sentence:
Let wâˆˆ(W) and say that (W',S') is the Coxeter system

  for some reduced expression  and distinct generators s,tâˆˆ
  S', exactly one of which is an odd endpoint of (W',S'), the
  following two conditions hold:
  
  
  * some cyclic shift of  is commutation equivalent to a
    reduced expression containing s,t_m(s,t)-1 as a subword;
  
  * neither s nor t appears elsewhere in .
  
  We analogously define an ts-band (i.e., some cyclic shift
  of  is commutation equivalent to a reduced expression containing
  t,s_m(s,t)-1 as a subword).  If we do not care to specify
  whether s or t comes first, then we will simply say that w has
  a band . An st-band is called small if m(s,t)=3,
  and large otherwise.

The decomposition above need not be unique.  We implicitly assume a

sentence: Let G(V,E) be a graph and vâˆˆ V(G). The clique substitution at v is the graph obtain from G by replacing v with a clique of size |N_G(v)| and matching vertices in N_G(v) with the vertices of that clique. sentence:
Let F be a connected plane partial 3-tree with maximum degree Î”, and 
let k be an integer. We say that a 3-tree H correctly covers F up 
to level k , if the following conditions are satisfied:


  * F is a spanning subgraph of H.

  * Let V^â‰¤ k denote the set of vertices that have level at most k in 
H. For every vertex vâˆˆ V^â‰¤ k there are at most 36Î” balanced 
edges of H that are incident to v.
                        
Furthermore, we say that H correctly covers F at all levels if, 
for any k, H correctly covers F up to levelÂ k.

sentence:
Let B be a nontrivial bubble in a tripod T. The unique internal face of 
B adjacent to its root edge will be called the root face ofÂ B. The 
dual of a bubble B is the rooted binary tree  whose nodes 
correspond bijectively to the internal faces of B, and two nodes are 
adjacent if and only if the corresponding faces of B share an edge. The 
root of the tree  is the node that represents the root face ofÂ B. 

When dealing with the internal faces of B, we will employ the usual 
terminology of rooted trees; for instance, we say that a face Î¦ is the 
parent (or child) of a face Î¨ if the node representing Î¦ in 
 is the parent (or child) of the node representing Î¨. For 
every internal face Î¦ of B, the three edges that form the boundary of Î¦ 
will be called the top edge , the left edge and the right 
edge , where the top edge is the edge that Î¦ shares with its parent face 
(or the root edge, if Î¦ is the root face), while left and right edges are 
defined in such a way that the top, left, and right edge form a 
counterclockwise sequence on the boundary of Î¦. With this convention, we 
may speak of a left child face or right child face of Î¦ without any 
ambiguity. Our terminology is motivated by the usual convention of embedding 
rooted binary trees with their root on the top, and the parent, the left child 
and the right child appearing in counterclockwise order around every node of 
the tree. Furthermore, for a given face Î¦, the bottom vertex of 
Î¦ is the common vertex of the left edge and right edge of Î¦.

sentence:
An adder A is a bubble with a root edge h and another edge tâ‰  
h, such that the dual tree of A is a path, and the edge t is an external 
edge adjacent to the single leaf face of A. See FigureÂ <ref>. The 
edges h and t are called head and tail of the adder. It is 
easy to see that every adder contains a unique path Z whose first edge is 
h, its last edge is t and no other edge of Z belongs to the outer face 
of A. The path Z will be called the zigzag path of the adder A. 
The length of the adder is defined to be the number of edges of its 
zigzag path. By definition, each adder has length at least 2. An adder of 
length 2 will be called degenerate .

sentence:
A finite point-line
incidence structure is called linear space
if each line contains at least two points and any
two distinct points are on exactly one line.
If there are exactly r lines through each point, then the linear space
is called (r,1)-design .

A (v_r,b_k)-configuration is a finite point-line incidence
structure with the following properties:


  * There are v points and b lines.

  * There are r lines through each point and there are
k points on each line.

  * Two distinct lines intersect each other at most once
and two distinct points are connected by at most one line.


If v=b and r=k, then the configuration is called
symmetric (v_k)-configuration .

sentence:
A connected and locally finite planar graph G is a planar tessellation , or just tessellation , if it satisfies the following conditions.



  (i) Every edge is contained in exactly two different faces.

  (ii) Every bounded face is a polygon: it is homeomorphic to the closed disk ğ”», and its boundary is a simple cycle (i.e. a finite path in which the first and the last vertices coincide). The edges of the cycle are called sides of the polygon.

  (iii) The intersection of any two distinct faces are either an empty set, or a vertex, or an edge.

sentence:
[Tessellation]
A connected and locally finite planar graph G is a planar tessellation , or just tessellation , if it satisfies the following conditions.



  (i) Every edge is contained in exactly two different faces.

  (ii) Every bounded face is a polygon: it is homeomorphic to the closed disk ğ”», and its boundary is a simple cycle (i.e. a finite path in which the first and the last vertices coincide). The edges of the cycle are called sides of the polygon.

  (iii) The intersection of any two distinct faces are either an empty set, or a vertex, or an edge.

sentence:
[Reduction of a hexagon] 
Let K be a pseudohex, h a hexagon of K and N a perfect matching of h. We define the 
reduction of h by N as follows.
For each of the three paths P_i, i=1,2,3, consisting of one edge of N and the white edges adjacent 
to this edge we introduce a new white edge e_i between the end-vertices of P_i
whenever P_i is not a cycle of length 2. If P_i is not a cycle of length 2, then 
for each red edge {u,w} attached to an interior vertex 
w of P_i we introduce new red edge {u,w'} where w' is the vertex of e_i of the same bipartition 
class of K as w. If P_i is a cycle of length 2, then for each red edge {u,w} attached to an interior vertex 
w of P_i we introduce a new red edge {u,uÌ…}.
Finally, we delete the vertices of h.
The paths P_i,  i= 1,2,3, are said to be contracted .

sentence:
A network in ğ’©(ğ’¯) is either an edge, whose endvertices are the poles, or is of type S ( series network ), or of type P ( parallel network ), or of type H ( core network ). 

Series networks: 
A network of type S consists of two networks N_1 and N_2, such that the right pole of N_1 is identified with the left pole of N_2. Here, N_1 is restricted to be either an edge, or of type S or H, and N_2âˆˆğ’©(ğ’¯). 

Parallel networks:
A network of type P consists either of an edge and a non-empty set of networks, 
either of type S or of type H, where 
their right poles (left poles) are identified into a single right pole (left pole), or a set of networks of size at least 2, either of type S or of type H where the identification of the poles is as before.

Core networks: Let ğ’¯Ì… be the class of networks which are created by taking any graph in , deleting an edge, and then turning its endvertices into poles. A network of type H consists of a network from ğ’¯Ì…, where each edge is replaced by a network whose poles are identified in a unique way with the endvertices of the edges. 

In any of the above cases, we do the necessary relabeling in case there are conflicts, when two or more networks are joined through one of the above operations. 


    < g r a p h i c s >

Î” = Î” (Î´, ) = {z  :  |z|< Ï_TÌ… (y) + Î´,  (z-Ï_TÌ…(y))> }.
Moreover, the smallest integerÂ k such that t_k(y)â‰¢0 and k/m âˆ‰â„• satisfies k/m = Î±. Also, the function Ï_TÌ…(y) is strictly decreasing and continuously twice differentiable.

A Baxter slicing (see an example in FigureÂ <ref>(b)) of size n is a parallelogram polyomino P of size n whose interior is divided into n blocks as follows:

and the other n-1 blocks form a Baxter slicing of the parallelogram polyomino of size n-1 obtained by deletion of the topmost row (resp.Â rightmost column) of P.

sentence:
A path of size n is a sequence of North (N = (0,1)) and East (E=(1,0)) steps, containing n-1 steps in total. 
Given three paths u, m, and d of the same size n, 
all containing the same number of E (and N) steps, 
(u,m,d) is a triple of non-intersecting lattice paths (for short, triple of NILPs) of size n 
when the embeddings of u, m and d in the plane never meet, 
with u (resp.Â m, resp.Â d) starting at the point of coordinates (0,2) (resp.Â (1,1), resp.Â (2,0)).

sentence:
Let (u,m,d) be a triple of NILPs as in DefinitionÂ <ref>. 

A pair (N_u,N_m) of N steps of u and m is matched 
if there exists i such that N_u (resp.Â N_m) is the i-th N step of u (resp.Â m).
Similarly, a pair (E_m,E_d) of E steps of m and d is matched 
if there exists i such that E_m (resp.Â E_d) is the i-th E step of m (resp.Â d).

Moreover, for any N step N_u in u (resp.Â N_m in m), 
we denote by h_u(N_u) (resp.Â h_m(N_m)) the number of E steps of u (resp.Â m) that occur before N_u (resp.Â N_m). 
And for any E step E_d in d, we denote by k_d(E_d) the largest k such that E^k is a factor of d ending in E_d.

sentence:
[Nonstandard concepts]  Let G be a nonstandard additive group, and let A, B be nonstandard finite subsets of G.


  (i) We say that A is small if its cardinality |A| is a standard natural number, and large otherwise.  (Note that A is small if and only if it is (externally) finite.)  We say that A,B have comparable size if |A| â‰ª |B| â‰ª |A|.

  (ii)  We say that A is somewhat sum-closed if Ï•(A) is (standardly) finite. 

  (iii) We write

    A+B := { a+b: a âˆˆ A, b âˆˆ B }
 
for the Minkowski sum of A and B, and say that A has bounded doubling if |A+A| â‰ª |A|.  For instance, any coset x+H of a nonstandard finite group H is of bounded doubling.

  (iv) For any standard natural number l, we write lA = A + â€¦ + A for the l-fold iterated sumset of A.  (
Although it can be done, we will not need to define lA for unbounded l.)

  (v) We say that A avoids B if |A âˆ© B| = o(|B|), and occupies B if it does not avoid B (or equivalently, if |A âˆ© B| â‰« |B|).  For instance, if A and B are groups, A avoids B when A âˆ© B has (externally) infinite index in B, and A occupies B when A âˆ© B has (externally) finite index in B.  See also Figure <ref>.

  (vi)  We say that A and B are commensurate if they occupy each other, and transverse if they avoid each other.  

  (vii) A sequence A_n of sets indexed by standard natural numbers n is said to be an wandering sequence if for every standard natural numbers n,m, we have (A_n+A_m) âˆ© (A_n+A_m') = âˆ… for all but finitely many m'.  For instance, if x_n+H is a sequence of disjoint cosets of a single nonstandard finite group H, then the x_n+H form an wandering sequence.

  (viii) We say that A has the wandering property if the sequence nA is an wandering sequence, or equivalently that nA âˆ© n'A = âˆ… whenever n' is sufficiently large depending on n.  For example, a coset x+H of a nonstandard finite group H has the wandering property if and only if x has infinite order in G/H, or equivalently if nx âˆ‰H for any standard n.  As another example, if G = ^* are the nonstandard integers and N is an unbounded natural number, then the nonstandard interval { n âˆˆ^* : N â‰¤ n < 2N } has the wandering property, but the nonstandard interval { n âˆˆ^* : 1 â‰¤ n â‰¤ N} does not.  

All of the above notions are understood to be restricted to nonstandard finite sets; for instance, if we say that A is large, it is understood that A is also nonstandard finite.

sentence:
For any I âŠ‚{1,â€¦,m+1}, write H_I for the subgroup H_I := â‹‚_i âˆˆ I H_i (this subgroup may be trivial), with the convention H_âˆ… = G.  If d is a natural number, a subspace[Since it is possible for H_I to equal H_J for distinct I,J, we should strictly speaking define a subspace to be a pair (x+H_I, I) rather than just x+H_I, otherwise concepts such as the codimension of the subspace would be undefined.  However, we shall abuse notation and use x+H_I rather than (x+H_I,I) to denote a subspace.] of G of codimension d to be a coset x+H_I of one of the H_I with |I|=d (note that no such subspaces exist if d>m+1).  If the codimension is one, we call the subspace a hyperplane , that is to say a hyperplane is a coset x+H_i of one of the H_1,â€¦,H_m+1.   A subspace x+H_I is said to be aperiodic if  nx+H_I is occupied by one of the H_1,â€¦,H_m+1 for some natural number n, and periodic otherwise.  Thus for instance G = H_âˆ… (the unique subspace of codimension 0) is aperiodic for vacuous reasons, and any aperiodic subspace of codimension at least one has the wandering property.  We say that a subspace x+H_I is captured by another subspace y+H_J if x+H_I âŠ‚ y+H_J and I âŠƒ J.

A core is a set of the form C = H'_1 âˆªâ€¦âˆª H'_m+1, where each H'_i is a group containing H_i as a commensurate subgroup.  If C is a core, a C-residual set is a set of the form A \ C' where C' is a core containing C.  A subspace x+H_I is said to be C-involved it has codimension at least one, and there exists a large C-residual set A' that is occupied by x+H_I.

sentence:
Let C be the partially shaded current tree and F the final tree. 

We say a supply node   is well-connected if all edges that are incident to  in 
F exist in the current tree C and are shaded ('nothing left to insert'). Otherwise it is open . 

A demand node  is well-connected if it is not incident to an unshaded edge in C ('nothing to delete'). 
Otherwise it is open .

A shaded edge incident to at least one well-connected node is a well-connected edge .

sentence: Given a graph G representing a position in a game of narrow Dots-and-Boxes/Triangles, let V_BG be the set of all vertices that are incident to an exterior leg, incident to an interior leg, or part of a path joining two vertices that are both incident to legs. Then the graph induced by V_BG and the ground vertex is called the base graph . Any vertices and edges that are not part of the base graph are said to be pendant vertices and pendant edges , respectively.

sentence:
A chain of length kâ‰¥0 is a collection of k+1 edges in the base graph satisfying one of the following.
 

  
  * Every interior leg is a chain of length zero.

  
  * An exterior leg together with the edges of the path connecting it to the nearest interior leg in the same component comprise a chain, which excludes the interior leg.

  
  * Edges of the path connecting two consecutive interior legs in the same component comprise a chain, again excluding the interior legs.

  
  * If a component has two exterior legs and no interior legs, then all edges of the base graph in that component comprise a chain of length at least two.

sentence:
Let G be a Î“-gain graph with edge colouring Î´: E(G) â†’{red, blue}.
	We define the following:
	
		
  * G^Î´_red := (V(G),{ e âˆˆ E(G) : Î´(e) = red}).
		
		
  * A red component is a connected component of G^Î´_red.
		
		
  * A red walk (respectively, red circuit ) is a walk (respectively, circuit) where every edge is red.
		
		
  * An almost red circuit is a circuit with exactly one blue edge.
		
		
  * G^Î´_blue, blue components , blue walks ,
		blue circuits , and almost blue circuits are defined analogously. 
		
		
  * We define monochromatic components , monochromatic walks ,
		monochromatic circuits and almost monochromatic circuits to be either red or blue. 

	A colouring Î´ is a NBAC-colouring ( No Balanced Almost Circuits )
	if it is surjective
	and there are no balanced almost red circuits and no balanced almost blue circuits;
	see Figure <ref> for an example of an NBAC-colouring.

sentence:
Let G be a â„¤^2-gain graph with an NBAC-colouring Î´.
	We define the following:
	
		
  * If both G^Î´_red and G^Î´_blue are balanced,
		then Î´ is a type 1 flexible 2-lattice NBAC-colouring.
		
		
  * If there exists Î±,Î²âˆˆâ„¤^2 
		such that 
		
			
  * either Î±,Î² are linearly independent or exactly one of Î±,Î² is equal to (0,0),
			
			
  * (G^Î´_red) is a non-trivial subgroups of  â„¤Î± or Î±=(0,0), 
			
			
  * (G^Î´_blue) is a non-trivial subgroups of  â„¤Î² or Î²=(0,0),
			
			
  * there are no almost red circuits with gain in â„¤Î±, and
			
			
  * there are no almost blue circuits with gain in â„¤Î²,
		
		then Î´ is a type 2 flexible 2-lattice NBAC-colouring.
		
		
  * If there exists Î±âˆˆâ„¤^2 âˆ–{(0,0)} such that
		
			
  * (G^Î´_red) and (G^Î´_red) are non-trivial subgroups of â„¤Î±, and
			
			
  * there are no almost monochromatic circuits with gain in â„¤Î±, 
		
		then Î´ is a type 3 flexible 2-lattice NBAC-colouring.

sentence:
In the case where open knot type is one of the overcrossing closure , undercrossing closure , or the over-undercrossing closure , open knot type is invariant under the usual Reidemeister moves ( i.e. those which do not interact with the loose ends).

  In the case where open knot type is the min-closure knot type, the min-closure knot type is not invariant under Reidemeister moves. However, we have that any two knotoid diagrams S, S' related by a sequence of Reidemeister moves are not orthogonal in the vector space of knot types; âŸ¨ [S], [S'] âŸ© > 0.

  By definition, any two knotoid diagrams with the same knotoid type are furthermore related by a sequence of Reidemeister moves.

sentence:
Let S be a knotoid diagram of at least one crossing and a, z its loose flags. Say that a is connected to a crossing v joining flags a,b_1,c_1,d_1, oriented counterclockwise (namely, flag c_1 meets the crossing opposite a). Say that the latter three flags are part of edges e_b = (b_1b_2), e_c = (c_1c_2), and e_d = (d_1d_2).

  Then the contraction Sa of S by flag a is the new knotoid diagram produced by deleting crossing v, edges e_b, e_c, e_d, and flags a, b_1, c_1, d_1 and inserting the edge e = (b_2d_2) joining flags b_2 and d_2. Sa is a new knotoid diagram with one fewer crossing, two fewer edges, and loose flags c_2 and z.

    a knotoid diagram D and its contraction along flag a, D-a.
    The diagram D has knot type [D] = 1/24_1 + 1/20_1,
    while the knot type of the contraction is [D-a] = 0_1.
    
  

  If S has precisely one crossing, then its contraction (by either flag) is the â€œtrivialâ€ knotoid diagram.

  If T is a knotoid diagram with no more crossings than S, then say S contains T as a knotoid diagram , T â‰¤ S, if S = T or there exists a series of contraction operations on S that produces the knotoid diagram T. If D is a diagram with as many or more crossings than T, then say D contains T (T â‰¤ D) as a knotoid diagram if there exists an edge e in D so that Dâˆ– e contains T.

sentence:
Consider a knotoid diagram S with loose flags a, z. An open knot type of S is an equivalence class of S under some equivalence relation. We only consider open knot types who satisfy analogous characteristics to the MDS methodÂ <cit.> of identifying subknots in open space polygons:
  
  
  * The open knot type of a knotoid diagram does not change under small perturbations.
    
  
  * The open knot type of a knotoid diagram which is â€œalmost closedâ€ is the same as that of the â€œobvious closureâ€. That is, the type of the knot diagram [D] is equivalent to the type of the knotoid diagram [D âˆ– e].

sentence:
For any set Î© of non-negative integers which contains 0,1 and at least one integer greater than 1, a (k,Î©)-front coding tree of size n is a tree T consisting of (kn+1) white nodes and n black nodes which satisfies:


  * T is rooted at a white node, every white node has only black nodes as children and every black node has only k white nodes as children.

  * The number of black children of the white root belongs to the set Î© and the number of black children of any other white node belongs to the set {i | i+1âˆˆÎ©,iâ‰¥ 0}.

  * The white root of T is labeled by a k-subset A of [n+k]={1,2,â€¦,n+k} and the black nodes are labeled by the integers from the set [n+k]-A such that for every white node, the subtrees stemming from its black children are not ordered between themselves.

The labels on the white root and black nodes determine the labels on the rest white nodes. We start from the white root and recursively label other white nodes. For every white node, we label it with a set {r_1,â€¦,r_i-1,r,r_i+1,â€¦,r_k} if the white node is the i-th child (from left to right) of a black node labeled by r and the white parent of this black node is labeled with the set {r_1,â€¦,r_k}.

If the white root of a (k,Î©)-front coding tree has precisely one black child, we call it reduced (k,Î©)-front coding tree.

sentence:
[the 231-conditions]
If F is a Ferrers board and S is an F-sequence, then the 231-conditions for the pair (F,S) are the following three conditions:



  (i)  (monotonicity conditions)  If V_1 and V_2 are vertices on the right/up border and V_1 is either directly to the left of V_2 or directly below V_2 then S(V_1)â‰¤ S(V_2)â‰¤ S(V_1)+1.

  (ii) (0-conditions)  The first and last values of S are 0, and there do not exist consecutive vertices V_1 and V_2 such that S(V_1)=0=S(V_2).

  (iii) (diagonal condition) If V_1 and V_2 are vertices on the right/up border that are at the left and right ends of a diagonal with slope -1 that lies entirely within F, then S(V_1)â‰¤ S(V_2).

sentence:
[the 312-conditions]

sentence:
Let S^*= (S,c^*) be a starred strong tableau of rank m.  Fix
  1<i<m.  Consider the locations of (i-1)^*, i^*,(i+1)^* in
  S^*.  The i-witness , or simply the witness
  when i is fixed, is chosen among {i-1,i,i+1 } as follows.

  
  
  * If c_i-1â‰  c_i+1, then c_i-1,c_i,c_i+1 are
    all distinct since p-ribbons and p+1-ribbons cannot have 
    head or tails of the same content by the analysis in SectionÂ <ref>. 
    In this case, the witness is the index of
    the median of the set {c_i-1,c_i,c_i+1}.
  
  * If c_i-1=c_i+1, then we have three cases to consider.
    
    
  * If the (i-1)-ribbons and (i+1)-ribbons have the same
      length, then i+1 is the witness .
    
  * If the (i-1)-ribbons and (i+1)-ribbons have different lengths
      and c_i-1>c_i, then the witness is the letter
      indexing the longer ribbons among the (i-1)-ribbons and the
      (i+1)-ribbons.
    
  * If the (i-1)-ribbons and (i+1)-ribbons have different
      lengths and c_i-1<c_i, then the witness is the
      letter indexing the shorter ribbons among the (i-1)-ribbons
      and the (i+1)-ribbons.

sentence:
[Function Density Problems]

Let ğ’ be a set of some functions, and let ğ’' be a subset of ğ’.
Let d(Â·,Â·) be a distance function for the pairs of functions in ğ’.
In this setting, we define a Function Density Problem to be a problem of estimating the following quantity:

    r(ğ’,ğ’') := sup{ d(f,ğ’') | f âˆˆğ’},

where, for each f âˆˆğ’, d(f,ğ’') := inf{ d(f,g) | g âˆˆğ’'} is the distance from f to ğ’'.
(The symbol r' stands for radiusâ€, by an analogy as if ğ’' is a single central point in the figure ğ’, in which case the r is the radius of ğ’ in usual sense.)

sentence:
Given two maintenance strategies gâˆˆâ„’_R(J, G) and fâˆˆâ„’_R(H, J), we construct Left's residual strategy gâŠ› f as follows.

Consider a Right move from [ G,H] to [ G^R,H]. We will find a Left's maintenance response, given the candidate morphisms f and g.
      
           Set up the two games [ G, J] and [ J, H], corresponding to the maintenance strategies f and g respectively; see the  columns of FigureÂ <ref>. 
           
           If Left's maintenance response in [G^R,J] is to [G^RL,J], then adapt this maintenance strategy for the game 
           [G^R,H], as [G^RL,H]. 
           
           If Left's maintenance response in [G^R, J] is to [G^R,J^R] then Left considers instead her maintenance response to the Right move in the game [J^R, H]. If this is [J^R,H^R], then her response in [G^R, H] is to [G^R,H^R]. If, instead, the response is to some [J^RL, H], she swivels back to the game [ G^R,J^RL], and finds a response to this Right move, and so on. 
           
           In case [G^R,J^R] is a terminal position, then, because  [J^R, H] is a Right's move in a Left Maintenance Strategy, there must exist a Right move in H^R, and so the play will terminate in [G^R,H^R], with a Left win (recall the Left Maintenance Game is normal-play).
           
           In either case, by continuing this idea, because J is finite and because f and g are maintenance strategies, eventually Left's response shifts to either of the forms [ G^RL,J^Î± ], with Î±=RLâ€¦ L or [ J^Î±,H^R] with Î±=RLâ€¦ R (i.e. Î± is a finite sequence of alternating moves). In the first case, the response in [ G^R,H] will be to [ G^RL,H] and in the second case it will be to [ G^R,H^R].  Unless this is a terminal position, we may iterate the argument. 
          
The construction of gâŠ› f in the case of the Right move [ G,H^L] is analogous.

sentence:
[Left's Residual Strategy]

Given two maintenance strategies gâˆˆâ„’_R(J, G) and fâˆˆâ„’_R(H, J), we construct Left's residual strategy gâŠ› f as follows.

Consider a Right move from [ G,H] to [ G^R,H]. We will find a Left's maintenance response, given the candidate morphisms f and g.
      
           Set up the two games [ G, J] and [ J, H], corresponding to the maintenance strategies f and g respectively; see the  columns of FigureÂ <ref>. 
           
           If Left's maintenance response in [G^R,J] is to [G^RL,J], then adapt this maintenance strategy for the game 
           [G^R,H], as [G^RL,H]. 
           
           If Left's maintenance response in [G^R, J] is to [G^R,J^R] then Left considers instead her maintenance response to the Right move in the game [J^R, H]. If this is [J^R,H^R], then her response in [G^R, H] is to [G^R,H^R]. If, instead, the response is to some [J^RL, H], she swivels back to the game [ G^R,J^RL], and finds a response to this Right move, and so on. 
           
           In case [G^R,J^R] is a terminal position, then, because  [J^R, H] is a Right's move in a Left Maintenance Strategy, there must exist a Right move in H^R, and so the play will terminate in [G^R,H^R], with a Left win (recall the Left Maintenance Game is normal-play).
           
           In either case, by continuing this idea, because J is finite and because f and g are maintenance strategies, eventually Left's response shifts to either of the forms [ G^RL,J^Î± ], with Î±=RLâ€¦ L or [ J^Î±,H^R] with Î±=RLâ€¦ R (i.e. Î± is a finite sequence of alternating moves). In the first case, the response in [ G^R,H] will be to [ G^RL,H] and in the second case it will be to [ G^R,H^R].  Unless this is a terminal position, we may iterate the argument. 
          
The construction of gâŠ› f in the case of the Right move [ G,H^L] is analogous.

sentence:
Let w = w_1 â€¦ w_n be a word in the alphabet X. We recursively construct a sequence (T_0,U_0), â€¦, (T_n, U_n) = (T,U) of tableaux, where T_i is a shifted Young tableau, and U_i is a standard shifted Young tableau, as follows. Set (T_0, U_0) = (âˆ…, âˆ…). For i = 1, â€¦, n, insert w_i into T_i-1 in the following manner:

Insert w_i into the first row, bumping out the smallest element a that is strictly greater than w_i (in the order given by the alphabet X').


  * if a is not on the main diagonal, do as follows:


  * if a is unprimed, then insert it in the next row, as explained above;

  * if a is primed, insert it into the next column to the right, bumping out the smallest element that is strictly greater than a;


  * if a is on the main diagonal, then it must be unprimed. Prime it, and insert it into the next column to the right.

The insertion process terminates once a letter is placed at the end of a row or column, bumping no new element. The resulting tableau isÂ T_i.

sentence:
[Mixed insertion]
Let w = w_1 â€¦ w_n be a word in the alphabet X. We recursively construct a sequence (T_0,U_0), â€¦, (T_n, U_n) = (T,U) of tableaux, where T_i is a shifted Young tableau, and U_i is a standard shifted Young tableau, as follows. Set (T_0, U_0) = (âˆ…, âˆ…). For i = 1, â€¦, n, insert w_i into T_i-1 in the following manner:

Insert w_i into the first row, bumping out the smallest element a that is strictly greater than w_i (in the order given by the alphabet X').


  * if a is not on the main diagonal, do as follows:


  * if a is unprimed, then insert it in the next row, as explained above;

  * if a is primed, insert it into the next column to the right, bumping out the smallest element that is strictly greater than a;


  * if a is on the main diagonal, then it must be unprimed. Prime it, and insert it into the next column to the right.

The insertion process terminates once a letter is placed at the end of a row or column, bumping no new element. The resulting tableau isÂ T_i.

The shapes of T_i-1 and T_i differ by one box. Add that box to U_i-1, and write i into it to obtain U_i.

We call T the mixed insertion tableau and U the mixed recording tableau , and denote them (w) and (w), respectively.

sentence:
A word of length n is called a permutation if it contains each of the letters 1,2,â€¦, n each exactly once. A shifted Young tableau of content (1,1,â€¦,1) will be called a Haiman tableau . In other words, a Haiman tableau is a standard shifted tableau, possibly with some primed off-diagonal entries.

Let w = w_1 w_2 â€¦ w_m be a word. Let (Î±_1, â€¦, Î±_m) be the content of w, i.e., Î±_i letters in w are equal to i. The standardization of w, denoted (w) is the permutation obtained by relabelling the elements labelledÂ i by Î±_1+â‹¯ + Î±_i-1+1, â€¦, Î±_1 + â‹¯ + Î±_i, from left to right.

The standardization of an SSDTÂ R, denoted (R) is the filling obtained by applying the same procedure used in the standardization of a word, namely, taking the order of the elements from (R).  Note that in general, any filling of a shifted shape with letters in X can be standardized, using this method.

The standardization of a shifted Young tableau T, denoted (T) is the Haiman tableau of the same shape, obtained as follows: Let Î± = (Î±_1, â€¦, Î±_m) be the content of T. For every i, the entries labelled i' or i are relabelled Î±_1 + â€¦ + Î±_i-1+1, Î±_1 + â€¦ + Î±_i-1+2, â€¦, Î±_1 + â€¦ + Î±_i-1 + Î±_i. One assigns these values in increasing order, starting from the boxes labelled i', from top to bottom, and then moving to the boxes labelled i, from left to right. If the old element in a box was primed, so is the new one. This procedure has been suggested by Haiman <cit.>.

[Age-dependent branching process]
We call a branching process age-dependent , if individuals have random life-lengths with distribution function F_ Y with F_ Y(0)=0.   Let c_i denote the number of critical i-dimensional cells of Î”.
  
  
  (a) The space Î” is homotopy equivalent to a cell complex Î”_c, called the Morse complex of Î” with respect to M , with c_i cells of dimension i for each iâ‰¥ 0, plus a single 0-dimensional cell in the case where the empty set is paired in the matching.
  
  (b) There is an indexing of the cells of Î”_c with the critical cells of Î” such that for any two cells Ïƒ and Ï„ of Î”_c satisfying (Ïƒ)=(Ï„)+1, the incidence number [Ï„:Ïƒ] in the cellular chain complex for Î”_c is given by
    
    [Ï„:Ïƒ]=âˆ‘_cw(c)

    where the sum is taken over all alternating paths c connecting Ïƒ with Ï„, i.e. with all sequences c=(Ïƒ,a_1,u(a_1),â€¦,a_t,u(a_t),Ï„) such that a_1 â‰ºÏƒ, Ï„â‰º u(a_t), and a_i+1â‰º u(a_i) for i=1,â€¦,t-1.
    For such an alternating path, the quantity w(c) is defined by

    where the incidence numbers on the right-hand side are taken in the complex Î”.

sentence:

  of P, i.e., it is a subset MâŠ† P Ã— P such that

  When (a,b) âˆˆ M, we write a=d(b) and b=u(a).

    a_1 â‰º u(a_1) â‰» a_2 â‰º u(a_2) â‰»â‹¯â‰º u(a_m) â‰» a_1

  We call such a (W_i)_iâˆˆ Aâˆˆ P(A,B) a multi-homomorphism , and we call A the test object and B the target object for the complex.
  The faces of _M(A,B) are partially ordered by Xâ‰¤ Y if and only if X_iâŠ† Y_i for all iâˆˆ A.

sentence:
Let G be a reduced plabic graph as above
with boundary vertices b_1,â€¦, b_n.  
The trip from b_i is the path 
obtained by starting from b_i and traveling along 
edges of G according to the rule that each time we reach an internal white vertex we turn 
right, and each time we reach an internal black vertex we turn left. 
This trip ends at some boundary vertex b_Ï€(i).  
If the starting and ending points of the trip are the same vertex b_j, 
we set the color of the fixed point Ï€(j)=j to match the orientation of the trip
(clockwise or counterclockwise.)



In this way we associate a decorated permutation 
Ï€_G=(Ï€(1),â€¦,Ï€(n)) to each reduced plabic graph G, which 
is called the 
decorated trip permutation of G.

sentence:
Let G be a directed graph (possibly with multiple
edges). We say that G is an input-output graph if
there exists two disjoint non-empty subsets, V_ and
V_, of the set of vertices of G such that the
following properties are satisfied. 

  * G does not contain a directed cycle. (Recall that a cycle
  is a closed path and that a path is directed if all the
  edges are oriented in the same direction.)


  * Each vertex of G lies on a directed path from some vertex
in V_ to some vertex in V_.

  * Every internal vertex has at least one incoming edge and at
least one outgoing edge.

  * Every input vertex has only outgoing edges and every output
vertex has only ingoing edges.

sentence:

T_e:_s(e)â†’_t(e) by its transpose
T_e^t:_t(e)â†’_s(e)

redistribute in some way the incoming and outgoing edges for

be a two-edge connected component, then we add two edges
between v and v', both with the same orientation, and
both having the identity matrix attached to them

sentence:
Given a graph G and vertex v, we define the (labeled) path tree T_v(G) of G with respect to v recursively as follows. If G is a tree, we define T_v(G) = G, and we say that v is the root of T_v(G). We also label the vertices of T_v(G) using the vertices of G. (In the recursive step, we will continue to label using vertices of G.)

For an arbitrary graph G, we first consider the forest which is the disjoint union of the labeled trees T_w(G âˆ–{v}) for each w âˆˆ N(v). We then define T_v(G) by appending a vertex (the root) labeled v and connecting it to the roots of each of these trees.

For an arbitrary graph G, we first consider the forest which is the disjoint union of the trees T^âˆ _w(G âˆ– N[v] âˆª{w}) for each w âˆˆ N(v). We then define T^âˆ _v(G) by appending a vertex corresponding to v (the root) and connecting it to the roots of each of these trees.

sentence: Given a graph G and a clique K, the induced path tree T^âˆ _K(G) of G with respect to K is defined as follows. Construct a new graph G^* by attaching a new vertex * to G, with the property that {*,u}âˆˆ E(G^*) iff u âˆˆ K. Then, define T^âˆ _K(G) := T^âˆ _{*}(G^*).

Given a simplicial graph G and simplicial clique K â‰¤ G, we define the (simplicial) clique tree T^âŠ _K(G) of G with respect to K recursively as follows. If G = K, we define T^âŠ _K(G) = G, and we say that K is the â€œroot cliqueâ€ of T^âŠ _K(G).

For an arbitrary graph G, we first consider the â€œforest of simplicial clique treesâ€ which is the disjoint union of T^âŠ _J_u(G âˆ– K) for each u âˆˆ K. (Here, we define J_u := N[u] âˆ© G âˆ– K.) Note that this is valid, since the previous lemma implies J_u is a simplicial clique for all u âˆˆ K. A tiered tree of size n is a pair (T,t) where:


  * T is a labeled tree on [n].

  * t is a surjective mapping from [n] â†’ [k] for some k such that for any edge (i,j) of T with i>j we have t(i) < t(j).

The function t is called the tiering function of the tiered tree (T,t), and the integer k is its number of tiers.

A tiered tree is said to be fully tiered if its number of tiers equals its number of vertices, that is, k=n, or equivalently, if its tiering function is a bijection.

Let G be a graph and H a subgraph of G isomorphic to a subdivision of K_3,3.  
Let v_1, v_2, â€¦, v_6 be the degree three vertices of H and for i=1,2,3 and j=4,5,6 let
P_ij be the paths in H between v_i and v_j.  
We then refer to H as a hex or a hex of G , the vertices v_i as the feet of H, 
and the paths P_ij as the segments of H.
A segment is odd if it has an odd number of edges, and even otherwise.
A hex H is odd if every segment of H is odd.

to various carefully selected paths R_1, R_2, R_3 to obtain replacement paths R_1', R_2', R_3' and new paths R_4' and, when appropriate, R_5'.

sentence:
[<cit.>]
Let ğ’¯ be a plane triangulation, and denote by
v_0,v_1,v_2 the outer vertices in counterclockwise ( ccw )
order around the outer face.
A Schnyder wood  of ğ’¯ is an orientation and
labeling, with labels in {0,1,2} of the inner edges of   so as
to satisfy the following conditions:





  * root-face condition: for iâˆˆ{0,1,2}, the inner edges incident to the
outer vertex v_i are all ingoing of color i.

  * local
condition for inner vertices: For each inner vertex v, the
edges incident to v in counterclockwise ( ccw ) order are: one
outgoing edge  colored 2,
zero or more incoming edges  colored 1,  one outgoing edge  colored
0, zero or more incoming edges  colored 2, one outgoing edge
 colored 1, and zero or more incoming edges  colored 0, which we write concisely as

    (( 1), 0, ( 2), 1,( 0), 2).

sentence:
Consider a genus g triangulation  with
n vertices, and having a root-face
f=(v_0, v_1, v_2) (the vertices are ordered according to a
walk along f with the interior of f on the right). Let  be
the set of inner edges of .
A g-Schnyder wood of  (also called genus g Schnyder wood)
is a partition of
  into a set of normal edges  and a set
â„°^s of
special edges considered as fat, i.e., each special edge is
 doubled into two edges delimiting a face of degree 2, called a special face .
 In addition, each edge, a normal edge or one of the two
edges of a special edge, is directed and has a
label (also called color) in {0,1,2}, so as to satisfy the following conditions:





  * root-face condition:
The outer vertex v_2 is incident to no special edges. All inner edges
incident to v_2 are ingoing of color 2.

Let kâ‰¥ 0 be the number of special edges incident to v_0 (each of these
special edges is doubled), and let L=(e_1,f_1,e_2,f_2,â€¦,e_r,f_r)
be the cyclic list of edges and faces incident to v_0 in ccw order (f_i
is the face incident to v_0 between e_i and e_(i+1) mod r).
A sector of v is a maximal interval of L that does not contain
a special face nor the root-face. Note that there are k+1 sectors, which are
disjoint; the one containing the edge {v_0,v_1} is called the root-sector .

Then, all inner edges in the root-sector are ingoing of color 0.
In all the other k sectors, the edges in ccw order are of the form

    ( 1), 0, ( 2), 1,( 0).

The definitions of sectors and conditions are the same for v_1,
except that all edges in the root-sector are ingoing of color 1.


  * local condition for inner vertices: Every
inner vertex v has exactly one outgoing edge e of color 2.
Let k be the number of special edges incident to v (each of these
edges is doubled and delimits a special face), and
let L=(e_1,f_1,e_2,f_2,â€¦,e_r,f_r)
be the cyclic list of edges and faces incident to v in ccw order.
A sector of v is a maximal interval of L that does not contain
a special face nor the edge e. Note that there are k+1 sectors around v,
which are disjoint.

Then, in each sector the edges in ccw order are of the form

    ( 1), 0, ( 2), 1,( 0).



  * Cut-graph condition: The graph T_2 formed by the edges of color 2
is a tree spanning all vertices except v_0 and v_1, and rooted at v_2,
 i.e.,  all
edges of T_2 are directed toward v_2. The embedded
subgraph G_2 formed by T_2 plus the two edges (v_0,v_2) and
(v_1,v_2)
plus the special edges (not considered as doubled here) is a cut-graph of ,
which is called the cut-graph of the Schnyder wood.

(Note that the cut-graph condition forces the number of special edges to be 2g.)

  _n be the collection of all partition matrices on [1,n]={1,â€¦,n}.

If X is a simplicial complex with a coloring f of V(X) we define the pattern of a face to be the multiset of colors on its vertices. If f is a proper coloring, in the sense that no two vertices connected by an edge receive the same color, we define the pattern complex X/f to be the simplicial complex on the set of colors of f so that a subset P of the colors of f is a face of X/f if and only if there is a face of X with P as its pattern.

Let R be a random geometric graph with parameters N and r, and let MÏ€ N r^2.
Let W= W(N)  Mr log N, and assume that W^-1 is an integer. Partition the unit square S into W^-1 horizontal 
rectangles of size
W Ã— 1
(the horizontal slabs ),
and also into
W^-1 vertical 
rectangles of size
1Ã— W
(the vertical slabs ).
For a horizontal slab L, a left-to-right crossing is a path 
v_0v_1 â€¦ v_k
contained in L
such that 
v_0 has distance â‰¤ r/5
to the left side of L,
v_k has distance â‰¤ r/5
to the right side of L,
and the distance between v_i and v_i+1
is â‰¤ r/2 for each 0â‰¤ iâ‰¤ k-1.
A top-to-bottom crossing

sentence:
<cit.> A graph-link is an equivalence class of labeled graphs under
the equivalence relation generated by the following operations.

Î©_g1. Adjoin or remove an isolated vertex with label (0, Â±).

Î©_g2. Adjoin or remove a pair of non-adjacent (resp. adjacent)
vertices that are labeled (0, Â±Î±) (resp. (1, Â±Î±)) and
have the same adjacencies with other vertices.

Î©_g3. Suppose G has three distinct vertices v, w, x labeled
(0, -), such that the only neighbors of x are v and w, which are not
neighbors of each other. Then change the labels of v and w to (0, +),
make x adjacent to every vertex that is adjacent to precisely one of v,
w, and remove the edges connecting x to v and w. (The inverse of this
operation is also an Î©_g3 move.)

Î©_g4. Suppose G has two adjacent vertices v and w labeled (0, Î±) and (0, Î²). Replace G with ((G^v)^w)^v and then
change the labels of v and w to (0, -Î²) and (0, -Î±)
respectively. (The inverse is also an Î©_g4 move.)

Î©_g4^'. Suppose G has a vertex v with label (1,
Î±). Replace G with G^v, change the label of v to (1,
-Î±), and change the label of each neighbor of v by changing the first
coordinate and leaving the second coordinate the same. (The inverse is also an
Î©_g4^' move.)

sentence:
The Gelfand-Serganova stratification 
(or thin cell stratification ) of G/P is the simultaneous
refinement of all the Schubert cell decompositions described above.
The (nonempty) strata in this decomposition are called Gelfand-Serganova
strata or thin cells .
In other words,  we choose for each Borel 
subgroup C a Schubert cell associated with C.  The intersection
of all chosen cells, if it is nonempy, is called a Gelfand-Serganova 
stratum or a thin cell.

sentence:
*The â„“-insertion procedure.
Let T be an element of _n,â„“. 
The â„“-special box of T is defined as


  * the right-most box of the â„“-th row, if the (â„“+1)-st row is strictly smaller;

  * the right-most dotted box at the bottom of a column, otherwise.

Given an integer m in {1,â€¦,n}, we associate to it an edge e_m of the South-East border of T
by labeling these edges from South-West to North-East.
Note that we exclude the (vertical) edges e_n+1,â€¦,e_n+â„“ at the right of the first â„“ rows of T.
As in the insertion procedure ofÂ <cit.>, if e_m is a horizontal (resp. vertical) edge of the border of T,
we add a row (resp. column) to T below (resp. to the right of) e_m,
composed of empty boxes except for one dotted box: the one below (resp. to the right of) e_m.
Next, if the dotted box added is to the left of the â„“-special box of T, we add a ribbon
(a connected  set of empty boxes without any 2Ã— 2 square) adjacent simultaneously to the â„“-special box of T
and to the dotted box added.

sentence:
A tree decomposition of a graph G=(V,E) is 
    a pair (T,â„¬={B_x}_xâˆˆ V(T)) 
    where T is a tree and for all xâˆˆ V(T), B_xâŠ† V which are called bags , 	
    satisfying the following three conditions:


  (T1) V=â‹ƒ_xâˆˆ V(T)B_x.

  (T2) For every edge uv of G, there exists a vertex x of T such that u, vâˆˆ B_x.

  (T3) For every vertex v in G, the bags containing v induce a subtree in T.

	The width of a tree decomposition (T,â„¬) is max{B_x-1:xâˆˆ V(T)}. 
	The treewidth of G, denoted by (G), is the minimum width of all tree decompositions of G. 
	A path decomposition of a graph G is a tree decomposition (T,â„¬) where T is a path. 
	The pathwidth of G, denoted by (G), is the minimum width of all path decompositions of G.

sentence:
[Bodlaender and KloksÂ <cit.>]

The class of trees of cycles is the class of graphs recursively defined as follows.

	
  * Each cycle is a tree of cycles.
	
  * For each tree of cycles G and each cycle C, the graph obtained from G and C by taking the disjoint union and identifying an edge and its end vertices in G with an edge and its end vertices in C, is a tree of cycles.

sentence:
[Bodlaender and de FluiterÂ <cit.>]

A path of cycles is a tree of cycles G for which the following holds.

	
  * Each chordless cycle of G has at most two edge separators.
	
  * If an edge e âˆˆ E is contained in m â‰¥ 3 chordless cycles of G, then at least m - 2 of these cycles are simplicial triangles.

[Bodlaender and de FluiterÂ <cit.>]

Let G be a path of cycles. Let C = (C_1,â€¦,C_p) be a sequence
of chordless cycles such that each chordless cycle in G appears exactly once in the sequence of cycles, and for 1â‰¤ iâ‰¤ p-1, C_i shares exactly one edge e_i with C_i+1. 
Let E = (e_1,â€¦,e_p-1) be the corresponding set of
common edges. The pair (C,E) is called a cycle path model for G.

sentence:
A chain tree of cycles is a tree of cycles G=(V,E) for which the following holds.


  * If an edge e âˆˆ E is contained in m â‰¥ 3 chordless cycles of G, then at least m - 2 of these cycles are simplicial triangles.

sentence:
A tree of two-boundaried cycles is a tree of cycles G for which the following holds. 


  * Each chordless cycle of G has at most two edge separators.

sentence:
The class of mamba trees is the class of graphs recursively defined as follows.

	
  * Each mamba is a mamba tree.
	
  * For each mamba tree G and each mamba M, the graph obtained from a disjoint union of G and M by identifying a vertex of G with a head vertex of M is a mamba tree.

sentence:
For a univariate polynomial fâˆˆ K[x_k], say f=âˆ‘_i=0^d c_i x_k^i with c_iâˆˆ K, c_0c_d â‰  0, the Newton polygon (or extended Newton polyhedron ) is defined to be

  Similarly, for a multivariate polynomial fâˆˆ K[x_1,â€¦,x_k], say f=âˆ‘_i=0^d f_iÂ· x_k^i with f_iâˆˆ K[x_1,â€¦,x_k-1] and a weight wâˆˆ^k-1, we define the expected Newton polygon of f at w to be

Let mâ‰¥ 2 be an integer. An m-constellation on ğ’®_g

only faces of different colours are adjacent.

multiple of m.

  (iii)
every vertex can be given a label in {1,â€¦,m} such that around every black face, 
the labels of the vertices read in clockwise order are exaclty 1,â€¦,m.

A map that satisfies conditions (i) and (ii) is called a
m-hypermap.

sentence:
(see FigureÂ <ref>)
A white split-edge is an edge that links a white
unlabelled vertex to a pair formed by two flags, each one lying on one side of the edge, as in
FigureÂ <ref>. Each flag is labelled by integer. If those labels are
l_1 and l_2, in clockwise order around the unlabelled vertex, the quantity
l_2-l_1+1 is called the type of the split-edge. The same definition
holds for black split-edges , but in this case the type is defined as
l_1-l_2-1.

A white elementary star is a star formed by a central white unlabelled
vertex, which is connected to a certain number of labelled vertices, and to a
certain number of white split edges, and that satisfies the property iii-w of DefinitionÂ <ref>. Elementary stars are considered up to
translation of the labels. 

The same definition holds for black elementary stars, up to replacing â€œwhiteâ€
by â€œblackâ€ and property iii-w by property iii-b.

sentence:
(see FigureÂ <ref>)
A cell of type 0 is a standard elementary white star of degree multiple
of m, which carries two distinguished labelled vertices: 
the in one and the out one.

 The increment of a cell of
type 0 is the difference l_-l_ of the labels of its out and in vertices. Its size is its number of 
split-edges, and its total degree is its degree as an elementary star
(i.e. the degree of the central vertex).

A chain of type 0 is a finite sequence of cells type 0. Its
size and increment are defined additively from the size and increment of the
cells it contains. Its in vertex (resp out vertex) is the in
vertex of its first cell (resp. out vertex of its last cell).

A linear [n,n-r]_q code has covering radius R and is denoted as an [n,n-r]_qR code if any of the following equivalent properties holds:

  (i) The value R

of a parity check matrix of the code, and R is the smallest value with
this property.
