sentence:
Let us define a graph G(T ) consisting of all the pairs covered by the hyperedges of the skeleton T. For a vertex v âˆˆ V (T ) and a vertex pair {x, y} such that xy âˆˆ E(G(T)), we say {x, y}  is opposite to v if x and y are at equal distance from v in G(T). This equal distance is also called the distance between v and the opposite pair {x, y}.
	
	Note that every hyperedge of T contains exactly one pair opposite to v.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a linear path {p_0q_0p_1, p_1q_1p_2, p_2q_2p_3, â€¦, p_k-2q_k-2p_k-1, p_k-1q_k-1p_k} of length k in H and a skeleton containing it, the set of hyperedges of this skeleton which contain p_1 (respectively p_k-1) except p_1q_1p_2 (respectively except p_k-2q_k-2p_k-1) is called as a windmill at p_1 (respectively p_k-1) and the size of this set is called the size of the windmill. In other words, windmill at p_1 is a star at p_1 minus the hyperedge p_1q_1p_2 (and similarly, windmill at p_k-1 is a star at p_k-1 minus the hyperedge p_k-2q_k-2p_k-1).

So there are two windmills corresponding to a linear path of length k and a skeleton containing it. The windmill of smaller size among the two is referred as the smaller windmill. If they are of same size, then either one can be considered as the smaller windmill. 

Note that as we assumed k â‰¥ 3, the two windmills do not have any hyperedges in common.

sentence:
A linear tree is a hypergraph obtained from a vertex by repeatedly adding hyperedges that intersect the previous hypergraph in exactly one vertex. 
	

	
	 A linear path ğ’« of length k â‰¥ 0 is an alternating sequence v_1,h_1,v_2,h_2,...,h_k, v_k+1 of distinct vertices and distinct hyperedges such that h_i âˆ© h_i+1 = {v_i+1} for each i âˆˆ{1,2,â€¦,k-1}, v_1 âˆˆ h_1, v_k+1âˆˆ h_k and h_i âˆ© h_j= âˆ… if j-iâ‰¥ 2. The vertex set V(ğ’«) of ğ’« is âˆª^k_i=1 h_i or {v_1} if k = 0.
	 
	  We say that ğ’« is a linear path between/joining v_1 and v_k+1 or in general, between vertex sets A and B if v_1 âˆˆ A, v_k+1âˆˆ B, h_i âˆ© A = âˆ… for 2 â‰¤ i â‰¤ k and h_i âˆ© B = âˆ… for 1 â‰¤ i â‰¤ k-1. Typically A and B are (vertex sets of) hyperedges or one element sets.
	
	A linear cycle of length k â‰¥ 3 is an alternating sequence v_1,h_1,v_2,h_2,...,v_k, h_k of distinct vertices and distinct hyperedges such that h_i âˆ© h_i+1 = {v_i+1} for each i âˆˆ{1,2,â€¦,k-1}, h_1 âˆ© h_k = {v_1} and h_i âˆ© h_j= âˆ… if 1 < j-i < k-1.
	
	A skeleton T in H is a linear subtree of H which cannot be extended to a larger linear subtree by adding a hyperedge e of H for which e âˆ© V(T) = 1.

sentence:
Given a vertex v âˆˆ V(H) and a hyperedge abc âˆˆ E(H) such that v âˆ‰{a,b,c}, we say that v is â€œstrongly associated" to abc if at least two of the three edges vab, vbc, vca are in E(H) . We say that v is â€œweakly associated" to abc if exactly one of the three edges vab, vbc, vca is in E(H). We say that v is associated to abc if it is either strongly or weakly associated.
	
	The set of pairs {{x,y}âŠ‚{a,b,c}| vxy âˆˆ E(H) } is called the â€œsupport" of v in abc, denoted s_abc(v) and these hyperedges vxy are called  â€œsupporting" hyperedges of v in abc.

sentence:
[star]
	
	Star of the skeleton T at v âˆˆ V (T) is defined as the subtree of T consisting of the hyperedges of T incident to v. The vertex v is called the center of this star.

sentence:
[opposite pair]
	
	Let us define a graph G(T ) consisting of all the pairs covered by the hyperedges of the skeleton T. For a vertex v âˆˆ V (T ) and a vertex pair {x, y} such that xy âˆˆ E(G(T)), we say {x, y}  is opposite to v if x and y are at equal distance from v in G(T). This equal distance is also called the distance between v and the opposite pair {x, y}.
	
	Note that every hyperedge of T contains exactly one pair opposite to v.

sentence:
[windmills]
Given a linear path {p_0q_0p_1, p_1q_1p_2, p_2q_2p_3, â€¦, p_k-2q_k-2p_k-1, p_k-1q_k-1p_k} of length k in H and a skeleton containing it, the set of hyperedges of this skeleton which contain p_1 (respectively p_k-1) except p_1q_1p_2 (respectively except p_k-2q_k-2p_k-1) is called as a windmill at p_1 (respectively p_k-1) and the size of this set is called the size of the windmill. In other words, windmill at p_1 is a star at p_1 minus the hyperedge p_1q_1p_2 (and similarly, windmill at p_k-1 is a star at p_k-1 minus the hyperedge p_k-2q_k-2p_k-1).

So there are two windmills corresponding to a linear path of length k and a skeleton containing it. The windmill of smaller size among the two is referred as the smaller windmill. If they are of same size, then either one can be considered as the smaller windmill. 

Note that as we assumed k â‰¥ 3, the two windmills do not have any hyperedges in common.

sentence:
[Crystal operators on fillings]
Let F âˆˆ(Î»/Î¼) and define the crystal biword WÌƒ,
with entry ([ j; c ]) appearing in WÌƒ
if and only if there is a box with value j in column c.
The entries in WÌƒ are then sorted decreasingly, primarily on the bottom row entry ,
see <ref>. 
Note that this is map to WÌƒ is invertible if Î»/Î¼ is fixed.
We then define _i(F), and _i(F) as the result when applying 
e_i and f_i, respectively, on the first row of WÌƒ.

For the subset of coinversion-free fillings F with (F)=0, 
these operators are essentially a generalization of the raisingâ€“ and lowering 
operators defined on semistandard Young tableaux.

sentence:
[Theorem 1.5.1, <cit.>] 
Let G=(V,E) be a graph with at least two vertices. Then the maximal strong submodules ( m.s.s. ) of G form a partition of V and exactly one of the following conditions hold:

	
  Parallel case G is not connected. Then its m.s.s. are its connected components.
	
  Serial case G is not connected. Then the m.s.s. of G are the connected components of G.
	
  Prime case Both G and G are connected. Then there is a subset UâŠ‚ V such that
		
			
  * #U > 3,
			
  * G_U is a maximal prime subgraph of G,
			
  * and every m.s.s. M of G has # Mâˆ© U = 1.

sentence:
A crystal graph of some crystal â„¬ is a directed, edge colored (with colors i âˆˆ I) graph with vertices in â„¬ satisfying the following:

  * for every vertex x âˆˆâ„¬ and i âˆˆ I, there is at most one edge z  x, and dually, at most one edge x  y. Here, we say that z=e_i(x) and y=f_i(x).

sentence:
We say that an edge colored directed graph, X, is A-regular if the axioms (S1)-(S6) and (S5')-(S6') are satsified:


  (S1) All monochromatic paths in X have finite length.

  (S2) For any vertex x âˆˆ X, there is at most one incoming edge, z  x, colored i and at most one outgoing edge, x  y colored i. Here, we say that z = e_i(x) and y = f_i(x), where e_i and f_i are crystal operators .

We can define the i-string through x to be:

    f_i^-d(x) â†’â‹¯â†’ f_i^-1(x) â†’ x â†’ f_i(x) â†’â‹¯â†’ f_i^r(x).
 
We can then define the i-rise of x to be Îµ_i(x) := r and the i-depth of x to be Î´_i(x) := -d. To measure the effect of the crystal operators e_i and f_i on the j-rise and j-depth of each vertex, we define the difference operators Î”_i to be:

    Î”_iÎ´_j(x) = Î´_j(e_i(x)) - Î´_j(x),   Î”_iÎµ_j(x) = Îµ_j(e_i(x)) - Îµ_j(x),

whenever e_i(x) is defined, and

    âˆ‡_iÎ´_j(x) = Î´_j(x) - Î´_j(f_i(x)),   âˆ‡_iÎµ_j(x) = Îµ_j(x) - Îµ_j(f_i(x)),

whenever f_i(x) is defined.


  (S3) For a fixed x âˆˆ X and i,j âˆˆ I such that e_i(x) is defined, we require Î”_iÎ´_j(x) + Î”_iÎµ_j(x) = a_ij,

  (S4) For a fixed x âˆˆ X and i,j âˆˆ I such that e_i(x) is defined, we require Î”_iÎ´_j(x) â‰¤ 0 and Î”_iÎµ_j(x) â‰¤ 0.

  (S5) For a fixed x âˆˆ X such that e_i(x) and e_j(x) are both defined, we require that Î”_iÎ´_j(x) = 0 implies e_ie_j(x) = e_je_i(x) and âˆ‡_jÎµ_i(y) = 0 where y = e_ie_j(x) = e_je_i(x).

  (S6) For a fixed x âˆˆ X such that e_i(x) and e_j(x) are both defined, we require that Î”_iÎ´_j(x) = Î”_jÎ´_i(x) = -1 implies e_ie_j^2e_i(x) = e_je_i^2e_j(x) and âˆ‡_iÎµ_j(y) = âˆ‡_jÎµ_i(y) = -1 where y = e_ie_j^2e_i(x) = e_je_i^2e_j(x).  


Dually, we have the additional two requirements for X to be A-regular ,

sentence: If we have an x such that (S5') holds, then we say there is a degree two Stembridge relation upward from x, namely f_if_j(x) = f_jf_i(x). Similarly, if we have an x such that (S6') holds, we say there is a degree four Stembridge relation upward from x, namely f_if_j^2f_i(x) = f_jf_i^2f_j(x). Dually, if we have an x such that (S5) holds, then we say there is a degree two Stembridge relation downward from x. Similarly, if we have an x such that (S6) holds, we say there is a degree four Stembridge relation downward from x.

sentence:
A symplectic link pattern (slp for short) of size k is a symplectic oriented link pattern, such that every arrow is oriented from right to left and every loop is oriented counterclockwise. 
In the same way, the natural notion of orthogonal link pattern (orlp for short)
 enhanced symplectic and enhanced orthogonal link pattern is obtained.

sentence:
A symplectic oriented link pattern (solp for short) of size l consists of a  set of l vertices 1,2,â‹¯ l together with a collection of oriented arrows between these vertices and a collection of oriented arrows with dots between these vertices, such that


  (B) every vertex is touched by at most one arrow;

  (SpOr) there are no loops of arrows without dots (that is, no arrows without dots from a vertex to itself).

We denote by _l the set of solps of size l.

sentence:

 vertices 1,2,â‹¯ l together with a collection of oriented arrows between these vertices and a collection of oriented arrows with dots between these vertices, such that


  (B) every vertex is touched by at most one arrow;

  (SpOr) there are no loops of arrows without dots (that is, no arrows without dots from a vertex to itself).

  (Or) there are no loops of arrows with dots (that is, no arrows with dots from a vertex to itself).

We denote by _l the set of oolps of size l.

sentence:
An enhanced symplectic oriented link pattern (esolp. for short) of size k of type (b_1,...,b_k) consists of a  set of k vertices 1,2,â‹¯,k together with a collection of oriented arrows between different vertices, unoriented loops and oriented arrows with dots between arbitrary vertices. 

Denote by x_i  the number of sources of arrows, by y_i the number of targets of arrows, by z_i the number of unoriented loops and by l_i the number of loops with dots at vertex i.
Then the following condition defines an esolp of such kind:


  (Sp) x_i+y_i+z_i-l_iâ‰¤ b_i holds for  each vertex i.

sentence:
An enhanced orthogonal oriented link pattern (esolp. for short) of size k of type (b_1,...,b_k) consists of a  set of k vertices 1,2,â‹¯,k together with a collection of oriented arrows and oriented arrows with dots between these vertices. 

Denote by x_i  the number of sources of arrows, by y_i the number of targets of arrows and by z_i the number of unoriented loops at vertex i.

sentence: A Dyck path of size n is a lattice path going from (0,0) to (n,n), using only north and east unit steps and staying weakly above the line x=y (also called the main diagonal ).
